table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand familiar words and very basic phrases concerning myself, my family and immediate concrete surroundings when people speak slowly and clearly.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand phrases and the highest frequency vocabulary related to areas of most immediate personal relevance (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, local area, employment). I can catch the main point in short, clear, simple messages and announcements.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand the main points of clear standard speech on familiar matters regularly encountered in work, school, leisure, etc. I can understand the main point of many radio or TV programmes on current affairs or topics of personal or professional interest when the delivery is relatively slow and clear.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand extended speech and lectures and follow even complex lines of argument provided the topic is reasonably familiar. I can understand most TV news and current affairs programmes. I can understand the majority of films in standard dialect.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand extended speech even when it is not clearly structured and when relationships are only implied and not signalled explicitly. I can understand television programmes and films without too much effort.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I have no difficulty in understanding any kind of spoken language, whether live or broadcast, even when delivered at fast native speed, provided I have some time to get familiar with the accent.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand familiar names, words and very simple sentences, for example on notices and posters or in catalogues.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can read very short, simple texts. I can find specific, predictable information in simple everyday material such as advertisements, prospectuses, menus and timetables and I can understand short simple personal letters.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand texts that consist mainly of high frequency everyday or job-related language. I can understand the description of events, feelings and wishes in personal letters.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can read articles and reports concerned with contemporary problems in which the writers adopt particular attitudes or viewpoints. I can understand contemporary literary prose.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand long and complex factual and literary texts, appreciating distinctions of style. I can understand specialised articles and longer technical instructions, even when they do not relate to my field.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can read with ease virtually all forms of the written language, including abstract, structurally or linguistically complex texts such as manuals, specialised articles and literary works.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can interact in a simple way provided the other person is prepared to repeat or rephrase things at a slower rate of speech and help me formulate what I'm trying to say. I can ask and answer simple questions in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar topics and activities. I can handle very short social exchanges, even though I can't usually understand enough to keep the conversation going myself.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can deal with most situations likely to arise whilst travelling in an area where the language is spoken. I can enter unprepared into conversation on topics that are familiar, of personal interest or pertinent to everyday life (e.g. family, hobbies, work, travel and current events).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can interact with a degree of fluency and spontaneity that makes regular interaction with native speakers quite possible. I can take an active part in discussion in familiar contexts, accounting for and sustaining my views.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can express myself fluently and spontaneously without much obvious searching for expressions. I can use language flexibly and effectively for social and professional purposes. I can formulate ideas and opinions with precision and relate my contribution skilfully to those of other speakers.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can take part effortlessly in any conversation or discussion and have a good familiarity with idiomatic expressions and colloquialisms. I can express myself fluently and convey finer shades of meaning precisely. If I do have a problem I can backtrack and restructure around the difficulty so smoothly that other people are hardly aware of it.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can use simple phrases and sentences to describe where I live and people I know.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can use a series of phrases and sentences to describe in simple terms my family and other people, living conditions, my educational background and my present or most recent job.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can connect phrases in a simple way in order to describe experiences and events, my dreams, hopes and ambitions. I can briefly give reasons and explanations for opinions and plans. I can narrate a story or relate the plot of a book or film and describe my reactions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can present clear, detailed descriptions on a wide range of subjects related to my field of interest. I can explain a viewpoint on a topical issue giving the advantages and disadvantages of various options.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can present clear, detailed descriptions of complex subjects integrating sub-themes, developing particular points and rounding off with an appropriate conclusion.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can present a clear, smoothly-flowing description or argument in a style appropriate to the context and with an effective logical structure which helps the recipient to notice and remember significant points.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write a short, simple postcard, for example sending holiday greetings. I can fill in forms with personal details, for example entering my name, nationality and address on a hotel registration form.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write short, simple notes and messages. I can write a very simple personal letter, for example thanking someone for something.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write simple connected text on topics which are familiar or of personal interest. I can write personal letters describing experiences and impressions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write clear, detailed text on a wide range of subjects related to my interests. I can write an essay or report, passing on information or giving reasons in support of or against a particular point of view. I can write letters highlighting the personal significance of events and experiences.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can express myself in clear, well-structured text, expressing points of view at some length. I can write about complex subjects in a letter, an essay or a report, underlining what I consider to be the salient issues. I can select a style appropriate to the reader in mind.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write clear, smoothly-flowing text in an appropriate style. I can write complex letters, reports or articles which present a case with an effective logical structure which helps the recipient to notice and remember significant points. I can write summaries and reviews of professional or literary works.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe myself, my family and my circle of friends and acquaintances, in very simple single phrases.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can sum up difficult contents orally with no effort, and give a precise rendering of important details in the process.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: During a presentation, I can reply to difficult questions, and defend my viewpoint.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In a fluent, effortless manner, and with relevant details, I can talk about ideas and experiences (past and present), and develop and present these in an interesting way.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: Through word stress or emphasis in sentences, I can highlight finer shades of meaning, e. g. when telling stories or anecdotes.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: With no preparation, I can talk about the issues and retell the contents of texts, films, interviews and media reports, in a detailed way.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can structure an argument systematically, stand up for key points, and underline relevant details.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give presentations (that I have prepared beforehand) in an interesting and lively manner, and awaken an audience’s interest in an issue. I can also highlight special aspects; draw attention to open questions; respond to objections or interjections; and round off my contribution with an appropriate conclusion (e. g. project descriptions; product presentations).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe complex facts or situations in a clear, very detailed way.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can narrate and talk about my experiences (past and present), my ideas, my job area and about texts read, with fluency and in great detail.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In a clear and structured way, I can describe the most varied sequences or processes, explain rules, and give more complex working (or other) instructions to enable others to act accordingly.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can sum up the contents of texts, commercial films, interviews, or reports in such a way that my audience will be clear about the main points.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: If I have the chance to prepare extensively, I can hold and convincingly argue a view, giving the advantages and disadvantages of various options and relating these to each other.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can formulate my intentions, plans and goals with precision; I can explain and give reasons for my point of view about topical issues.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: Regarding my areas of interest I can develop and give presentations (prepared in advance) that are well structured and lingustically clear, so that my audience can clearly recognise the main points, along with important supporting details. I can also react spontaneously to relevant questions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In a spontaneous and largely fluent way, I can give clear, detailed descriptions and accounts of very many topics related to my fields of interest and of specialisation.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can narrate what I have experienced, got to know or thought up, in a spontaneous, largely fluent and detailed manner.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In simple connected phrases and sentences, I can describe and explain charts or diagrams.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can expand on complex themes with ease, structuring my talk well and adapting it to the needs of my actual audience.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In really short, prepared single phrases I can state where I live.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In very short, prepared sentences I can tell people what training I go in for, or what my line of work is.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can introduce someone (e. g. a speaker, or a guest), using short, well-learnt sentences.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce short texts that I have listened to several times or that I may know by heart (e. g. rhymes/poems, slogans, songs, pop-songs).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce numbers, e. g. telephone numbers.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: Using several simple phrases and sentences, I can talk about and report on habitual and planned activities (e. g. my interests, schedule of work, daily schedule of activities, my weekends).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can talk about events and personal experiences (present or past, e. g. concerning my training or work), if I can prepare such statements.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe places familiar to me, in a series of simple phrases (e. g. where I live, my place of work, where I go on holiday).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe my training, or my present or most recent job, in simple phrases and sentences.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give a short, simple, prepared presentation on a topic with which I am familiar. I can reply to simple questions that are directly relevant if I can ask for some questions to be repeated.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: With the help of words or illustrations known in advance, I can prepare and tell simple stories and describe events or processes.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce short sections from texts read or listened to, using several simple sentences.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe objects, devices and their function, in simple ways.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce simple calculations (e. g. 3,5 by 2 equals 7), and describe simple shapes.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give an account of what I have heard, seen, or experienced, provided these areas and topics are familiar to me; I can also describe my feelings and reactions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give factual descriptions (e. g. concerning the weather, accommodation, school, work) and outline sequences of events in situations familiar to me (e. g. events in the course of a day; celebrations; job-related activities).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give well prepared uncomplicated short presentations, making things easy and interesting for my audience.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can present my opinions, plans, intentions and goals, and give simple reasons.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe pictures, and tell stories with the help of keywords or illustrations.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can narrate the content of a book or film, and say what I think of it.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce short factual texts in a simple way, while keeping to the structure of the original text.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In a simple but structured way, I can describe, explain or sum up job-related facts and sequences of events (or things related to my area of specialisation, e. g. of a scientific, technical, or business nature).

table.name: block_desp_examples
table.title: Ordering a meal

table.name: block_desp_examples
table.title: At the restaurant

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: knowledge

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: comprehension

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: application

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: analysis

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: synthesis

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: evaluation

table.name: block_desp_skills
table.title: listening

table.name: block_desp_skills
table.title: writing

table.name: block_desp_skills
table.title: reading

table.name: block_desp_skills
table.title: spoken production

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: A1

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: A2

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: B1

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: B2

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: C1

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: C2

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Reading on this Level means being able to understand single words, groups of words or very short simple phrases that are encountered in everyday life.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Understanding short, linguistically and argumentatively simple texts encountered in everyday life, in one’s training or in occupational roles. Essential information contained in such texts is understood. As opposed to A1, short connected sentences can be understood at this stage.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Understanding texts that are about frequent topics of everyday or work-related life which the reader is familiar with. As opposed to A2, sentence structures and vocabulary of these texts are more complex and wider; topic areas are more varied, and include current affairs and events (among other things) as well as the description of emotions; texts are longer.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Learners can write various types of text about a series of topics that are familiar or of personal interest. Compared to Level A2, vocabulary and linguistic structures are much more extensive, so that a wider range of topics can be covered in writing. The purpose of written pieces can be seen and understood clearly, even though mistakes may still occur, in the areas of spelling, vocabulary, grammar and structure.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Written texts about topics of immediate everyday concerns are linguistically and intellectually simple; set phrases are often used, and statements are joined together with the help of simple conjunctions such as and / but / because / first / then / afterwards / later. In comparison to Level A1, texts are longer.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Written texts about some few everyday topics consist of single words or of set phrases.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Texts encountered on this Level are about topics one is familiar with, either in spoken interaction or via the media; speakers use standard dialect clearly and at medium speed. As opposed to A2, topics are more varied and also include current affairs. The meaning of some unknown words can already be successfully deduced from the context.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: In everyday situations that learners are familiar with, the gist of statements can be understood in spoken interaction and when reproduced via the media. Clearly articulated speech is necessary; learners may ask for repetitions, or listen to audio texts several times. As opposed to A1, speaking speed is somewhat faster; there are fewer pauses for thought.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Single words, phrases and very simple sentences concerning familiar situations can be understood in direct communication as well as via the media when people speak slowly and clearly. Pausing for thought is needed. On this Level, listening to the same message or speech unit several times is standard procedure.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Can understand the main points of clear standard input on familiar matters regularly encountered in work, school, leisure, etc. Can deal with most situations likely to arise while travelling in an area where the language is spoken. Can produce simple connected text on topics that are familiar or of personal interest. Can describe experiences and events, dreams, hopes and ambitions and briefly give reasons and explanations for opinions and plans.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Can understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, local geography, employment). Can communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters. Can describe in simple terms aspects of his/her background, immediate environment and matters in areas of immediate need.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases aimed at the satisfaction of needs of a concrete type. Can introduce him/herself and others and can ask and answer questions about personal details such as where he/she lives, people he/she knows and things he/she has. Can interact in a simple way provided the other person talks slowly and clearly and is prepared to help.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Can understand the main points of clear standard input on familiar matters regularly encountered in work, school, leisure, etc. Can deal with most situations likely to arise while travelling in an area where the language is spoken. Can produce simple connected text on topics that are familiar or of personal interest. Can describe experiences and events, dreams, hopes and ambitions and briefly give reasons and explanations for opinions and plans.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Can understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, local geography, employment). Can communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters. Can describe in simple terms aspects of his/her background, immediate environment and matters in areas of immediate need.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Can understand and use familiar everyday expressions and very basic phrases aimed at the satisfaction of needs of a concrete type. Can introduce him/herself and others and can ask and answer questions about personal details such as where he/she lives, people he/she knows and things he/she has. Can interact in a simple way provided the other person talks slowly and clearly and is prepared to help.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: To be able to understand longer texts that present greater difficulty content-wise, sufficient prior knowledge is required in a given subject. Standard dialect is used, and there is no very disturbing background noise. As opposed to Level B1, these are linguistically more demanding contributions on a variety of topics which may go beyond the learner’s immediate range of interests. On this Level, another challenge is to be able to pick up details when texts are spoken at greater speed.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: I can read articles and reports concerned with contemporary problems in which the writers adopt particular attitudes or viewpoints. I can understand contemporary literary prose.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: I can interact with a degree of fluency and spontaneity that makes regular interaction with native speakers quite possible. I can take an active part in discussion in familiar contexts, accounting for and sustaining my views.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: I can present clear, detailed descriptions on a wide range of subjects related to my field of interest. I can explain a viewpoint on a topical issue giving the advantages and disadvantages of various options.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Clearly structured factual texts as well as creative texts can be written by learners at this Level, on topics that are of importance in our society: texts that sum up information, that explain various viewpoints, and that correspond to recognised types of text (e. g. diary entries, inner monologue, readers’ letters). As regards summaries of texts, the degree of difficutly in source texts will correspond to Level B2 in reading comprehension skills. As opposed to Level B1, topics here go beyond immediate personal everyday concerns; they are clearly structured; vocabulary and linguistic structures are extensive enough to allow learners to express their purpose of writing well.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Texts on almost any topic, with a degree of difficulty (regarding content or language), are understood well, even if their structure is not evident and some details are not clearly stated but only implied or hinted at. As opposed to B2, texts may present linguistic features of certain geographical areas or of (careless) colloquial speech (as is often the case in films and in TV serials), without impeding learners’ understanding much. Speaking speed corresponds to normal everyday speech.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: I can understand long and complex factual and literary texts, appreciating distinctions of style. I can understand specialised articles and longer technical instructions, even when they do not relate to my field.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: I can express myself fluently and spontaneously without much obvious searching for expressions. I can use language flexibly and effectively for social and professional purposes. I can formulate ideas and opinions with precision and relate my contribution skilfully to those of other speakers.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: I can present clear, detailed descriptions of complex subjects integrating sub-themes, developing particular points and rounding off with an appropriate conclusion.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Subjects from the most varied areas of knowledge and experience can be dealt with in writing, in a detailed, precise and appropriate way. As opposed to Level B2, learners on this Level can linguistically adapt their writing to a given target group. Vocabulary and linguistic structures are extensive enough for difficult aspects of facts or circumstances to be expressed clearly, for easy communication.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Understanding any kind of spoken text presents no difficulty any more. As opposed to C1, speech is understood even when it contains more pronounced regional features. Listening comprehension on this Level corresponds to that of educated native speakers.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: I can read with ease virtually all forms of the written language, including abstract, structurally or linguistically complex texts such as manuals, specialised articles and literary works.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: I can take part effortlessly in any conversation or discussion and have a good familiarity with idiomatic expressions and colloquialisms. I can express myself fluently and convey finer shades of meaning precisely. If I do have a problem I can backtrack and restructure around the difficulty so smoothly that other people are hardly aware of it.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: I can present a clear, smoothly-flowing description or argument in a style appropriate to the context and with an effective logical structure which helps the recipient to notice and remember significant points.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Texts of all possible varieties and types are written with ease, due to learners’ extensive vocabulary, and to their mastery of linguistic structures and stylistic devices. As regards style, texts are developed and presented that are interesting enough to facilitate readers’ understanding (even of difficult lines of thought) and which help them retain details. As opposed to Level C1, this is a linguistic and intellectual level which is usually reached by educated native speakers only.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: On this Level, readers can understand texts (non-fiction or literary texts) that clearly allow them to recognise a writer’s viewpoint, and which are about topics that are relevant to life in our society. Such texts may be used to extract essential information; or they may be scanned, to gain a first impression of them. As opposed to B1, these are linguistically more demanding texts with a much greater vocabulary, with more complex linguistic structures, and on a greater variety of topics.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Understanding most texts in detail is practically no problem – even texts that are difficult content-wise or linguistically. As opposed to Level B2, learners can now consciously differentiate between formal and informal speech, and can recognise finer stylistic qualities, e. g. in a literary text. Texts can be understood even though readers may not be familiar with a given specialisation. Dictionaries are used only if the exact meaning of a word cannot be inferred from the context, or to clarify detailed nuances.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Gaining an exact understanding of texts of all kinds, which presents not the least difficulty any more. As opposed to C1, learners on this Level succeed in reading with ease, texts that are very difficult regarding content and/or language, and which represent a challenge even for educated native speakers.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Very simple everyday conversations or exchanges are feasible when well-learnt short phrases or single sentences are used, and if the other person does his/her best to make the conversation a success. Linguistic correctness plays a lesser role here. Facial expression and gestures are much used to support what is said.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: The situation governing an interaction, and the topic, need to be familiar to speakers on this Level; spoken interaction will be very short, and will serve to exchange the most essential information only. Simple language structures and the relevant vocabulary are used correctly in the sense that the meaning of contributions becomes clear. As compared to A1, a wider vocabulary and more linguistic structures are at learners’ disposal, to cover a wider range of topics.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: In many familiar everyday or work-related situations, speakers can interact and communicate spontaneously about various topics, and contribute actively to an exchange. Mostly they succeed in communicating the essentials, even though mistakes or pauses may occur. Compared to Level A2, vocabulary and linguistic structures are much more extensive, so that a larger range of topics can be discussed with no preparation.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: In exchanges with native speakers (among others), on many different topics that are of importance in our society, learners can interact, reply to arguments, and uphold their own viewpoint with clarity. As opposed to Level B1, topics go beyond immediate everyday situations; vocabulary and linguistic structures at learners’ disposal are of such great range that a speaker’s own opinion can be expressed clearly and distinctly. Speakers succeed (more or less) in adapting what they say, to the other person or persons (register).

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Exchanges in all areas of personal and working life can be conducted very spontaneously and fluently. As opposed to B2, learners can adapt even better to the other person or persons, i. e. learners know exactly what to say to whom in what situation, and in what way. Vocabulary and linguistic structures are so extensive and can be used so precisely that an exchange can be kept going with no noticeable interruption.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: No effort is involved in conducting formal or informal exchanges spontaneously, with the most various interlocutors, and on the greatest possible variety of topics. As opposed to C1, more idioms and colloquial phrases are used: all in all, learners’ language resembles that of educated native speakers.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Speakers have a number of simple everyday expressions by heart, to communicate elementary information about themselves and others.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Speakers can give information about a few topics of everyday life using several phrases or sentences. The vocabulary required is known, and simple linguistic structures are used correctly, in the sense that the meaning of statements is clear even though elementary mistakes may occur. As opposed to Level A1, speakers can use coherent sentences to talk about things and matters present, past and future.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Speakers can speak in a coherent way about familiar topics such as everyday occurrences, topics related to training, to the world of work and to travelling; they can also give reasons for viewpoints. For these purposes they dispose of sufficient vocabulary. They pause sometimes, need to reformulate, and make mistakes: however, the intended meaning of statements comes across. As opposed to Level A2, vocabulary and linguistic structures are much more extensive, so that a wider range of topics can be covered, even without preparation.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Longer units of speech about a large number of topics (concerning a speaker’s personal or working life) contain important details and are clearly structured, or clearly highlight the speaker‘s own point of view. As opposed to Level B1, spoken production is spontaneous and fluent; vocabulary and linguistic structures are extensive enough for speakers to present topics in a well structured way, and to argue their own viewpoint logically and coherently. There are hardly any elementary mistakes any more that might distort meaning.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Topics in the most varied subject areas can be presented with such linguistic precision that audiences are clear about context and connections. As opposed to Level B2, speakers can use linguistic means that make quite clear the textual structure of complex thought and speech; linguistic ways and means that highlight certain aspects; and that round off a contribution with an appropriate conclusion. Speakers also have a range of idiomatic and colloquial phrases, and can well adapt to relevant addressees.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Oral contributions of all kinds are developed and presented in so interesting a way that recipients find it easy to follow even difficult lines of thought and to remember details. As opposed to Level C1, learners have reached a linguistic and intellectual level that is usually attained by educated native speakers only.
